dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, Host_B, we've got some pretty big news from, uh, late last year, regarding U.S. markets and, like, Chinese companies.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, Host B, we've got some pretty big news from, uh, late last year, regarding U S markets and, like, Chinese companies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, Host_A, it's, um, it's a pretty significant piece of legislation. We're talking about the Holding Foreign Companies Accountable Act.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, Host A, it's, um, it's a pretty significant piece of legislation. We're talking about the Holding Foreign Companies Accountable Act.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: President Donald Trump signed legislation that could remove Chinese companies from U.S. exchanges if American regulators are not allowed to review their financial audits. The Holding Foreign Companies Accountable Act will require companies to establish that they are not owned or controlled by a foreign government and allow the U.S. Public Accounting Oversight Board to review their financial audits.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Right, the one that essentially says, "Hey, if you're a Chinese company, you better let us look at your books."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, the one that essentially says, Hey, if you're a Chinese company, you better let us look at your books.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Holding Foreign Companies Accountable Act will require companies to establish that they are not owned or controlled by a foreign government and allow the U.S. Public Accounting Oversight Board to review their financial audits.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. It's, uh, it's really about giving the U.S. Public Accounting Oversight Board, or PCAOB, the green light to review their financial audits.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. It's, uh, it's really about giving the U S Public Accounting Oversight Board, or P C A O B, the green light to review their financial audits.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...and allow the U.S. Public Accounting Oversight Board to review their financial audits.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And also, like, proving they're not owned or controlled by, uh, a foreign government. Which, you know, is pretty clearly aimed at China.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And also, like, proving they're not owned or controlled by, uh, a foreign government. Which, you know, is pretty clearly aimed at China.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Holding Foreign Companies Accountable Act will require companies to establish that they are not owned or controlled by a foreign government... Although the legislation applies to companies from any country outside of the U.S., the bills measures are clearly intended to target Chinese companies, such as Alibaba Group, Pinduoduo and PetroChina.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. I mean, companies like Alibaba, Pinduoduo, PetroChinaâ€”they're all, uh, sort of in the crosshairs here.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. I mean, companies like Alibaba, Pinduoduo, PetroChina-they're all, uh, sort of in the crosshairs here.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...the bills measures are clearly intended to target Chinese companies, such as Alibaba Group, Pinduoduo and PetroChina.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, what's the timeframe here? Do they just get instantly kicked off the market?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, what's the timeframe here? Do they just get instantly kicked off the market?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Not immediately, no. They've got, um, a three-year grace period to actually comply with these requirements.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Not immediately, no. They've got, um, a three-year grace period to actually comply with these requirements.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The companies have a grace period of three years to comply with the requirement before facing the threat of losing access to U.S. stock markets, a key source of capital for the companies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [overlaps] Three years to get their ducks in a row, basically.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Three years to get their ducks in a row, basically.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And it's interesting because, uh, this legislation, while signed by Trump, had a lot of bipartisan support.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And it's interesting because, uh, this legislation, while signed by Trump, had a lot of bipartisan support.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: President Donald Trump signed legislation... The measure passed the House by unanimous voice vote after passing the Senate in another unanimous vote in May this year. Legislation taking a hard line against China have been receiving bipartisan support this year...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Which is kind of rare these days, isn't it? Especially when you're talking about, like, taking a hard line on China.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is kind of rare these days, isn't it? Especially when you're talking about, like, taking a hard line on China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. It shows, uh, a unified front, I guess, despite broader "declining tensions" the article mentions, this aspect is still strong.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. It shows, uh, a unified front, I guess, despite broader declining tensions the article mentions, this aspect is still strong.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Legislation taking a hard line against China have been receiving bipartisan support this year amid rising tensions on a variety of fronts between the worlds two largest economies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But China's always been really resistant to this, right? Like, citing national security for not letting overseas regulators poke around.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But China's always been really resistant to this, right? Like, citing national security for not letting overseas regulators poke around.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Chinese authorities have long blocked overseas regulators from inspecting local accounting firms, citing national security concerns.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's been their long-standing position. So, it'll be, um, interesting to see how this plays out.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's been their long-standing position. So, it'll be, um, interesting to see how this plays out.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, companies were, like, considering secondary listings in Hong Kong as a hedge, but now what?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, companies were, like, considering secondary listings in Hong Kong as a hedge, but now what?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, the article actually says some, um, have *avoided* secondary listings there. Which is a bit counter-intuitive if it's a hedge.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, the article actually says some, um, have avoided secondary listings there. Which is a bit counter-intuitive if it's a hedge.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In anticipation of the legislation, Chinese companies have pursued secondary listings in Hong Kong as a hedge against the potential ban from trading their shares in the U.S. Alibaba, NetEase and Yum China have already listed their shares in Hong Kong.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Hmm. So, the plot thickens. Maybe they're, uh, just hoping for the best with the three-year window?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hmm. So, the plot thickens. Maybe they're, uh, just hoping for the best with the three-year window?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Could be. But Hong Kong's still a massive IPO market regardless, second largest globally, even without these particular listings.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Could be. But Hong Kong's still a massive I P O market regardless, second largest globally, even without these particular listings.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Alibaba, NetEase and Yum China have already listed their shares in Hong Kong. The citys stock exchange will finish the year as the worlds second-largest IPO market after raising a total of $50 billion in new listings, according to data compiled by KPMG.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, definitely a space to watch, then.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, definitely a space to watch, then.
